study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether crocin (a component of saffron) could improve withdrawal syndrome, craving, and cognitive function in patients undergoing methadone maintenance treatment (MMT).
results_summary: Crocin supplementation significantly improved craving and withdrawal symptoms but had no effect on cognitive function parameters. The placebo group showed no such improvements.
population_specificity: 60 patients under MMT programs referred to a clinic in Kashan, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of saffron supplementation on inflammatory biomarkers (CRP, TNF-α, and IL-6) in adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant changes in CRP, TNF-α, or IL-6 levels overall, but subgroup analyses indicated reductions in CRP and TNF-α under specific conditions (e.g., baseline levels, dosage, and participant characteristics).
population_specificity: Adults, including subgroups like non-diabetic subjects and those with specific baseline biomarker levels.
study_duration: Varied, with <12 weeks showing effects in some subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of crocin (a component of saffron) on oxidative stress and inflammatory markers in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Crocin supplementation significantly reduced inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, TNF-ɑ, NF-κB, and IL-6) compared to placebo, but had no effect on malondialdehyde (MDA). The improvements were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: 50 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saffron supplementation on fasting glucose and inflammatory markers in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood glucose levels and decreased serum levels of TNF-α, while also down-regulating TNF-α and IL-6 mRNA expressions. The study concluded that saffron modulates glucose levels and inflammation in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: 60 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of saffron supplementation on clinical outcomes and metabolic profiles in patients with active rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly improved clinical outcomes, including reduced tender and swollen joints, pain intensity, disease activity score, and inflammatory markers, with no reported adverse effects. Some metabolic markers showed improvement, though not all differences between groups were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Women over 18 years old with active rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saffron supplementation on depression, anxiety, and CRP levels through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Saffron intake significantly reduced Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), Beck Anxiety Inventory (BAI), and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) scores but had no effect on Hamilton Depression Rating Scale (HDRS-D), Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale (HARS-A) scores, or CRP levels.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (meta-analysis of multiple RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically summarize and analyze the effects of saffron supplementation on serum glucose and lipid profiles.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly reduced serum triglycerides (TG) and total cholesterol (TC), increased HDL levels, but had no significant effect on LDL or fasting blood glucose (FBG).
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of saffron capsules on food craving, body weight, and depression in overweight women with mild-to-moderate depression compared to placebo.
results_summary: Saffron significantly reduced depression scores compared to placebo but had no significant effect on food craving. Patients in the saffron group showed fewer side effects.
population_specificity: Overweight women (BMI ≥ 25) with mild-to-moderate depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of saffron supplementation on blood pressure, lipid profiles, basophils, eosinophils, and clinical symptoms in patients with mild to moderate allergic asthma.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly improved clinical symptoms (e.g., shortness of breath, salbutamol use, activity limitation) and reduced blood pressure, triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, eosinophils, and basophils compared to placebo. Asthma severity also decreased, though not quite significantly (p = 0.07).
population_specificity: 80 patients (32 women, 48 men, aged 41.25 ± 9.87 years) with mild to moderate allergic asthma.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of saffron on lipid profile, glycemic control, and antioxidant status in overweight/obese individuals with prediabetes.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly improved fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, and antioxidant activity (DPPH radical scavenging) but did not affect lipid profile or anthropometric measures.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese individuals with prediabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of oral saffron supplementation in improving visual function in adults with mild/moderate age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: Saffron supplementation modestly improved best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) and reduced mfERG latency compared to placebo, with no significant difference in adverse events. Participants already taking AREDS supplements also showed improved BCVA and mfERG response density.
population_specificity: Adults over 50 years with mild/moderate AMD and vision >20/70 Snellen equivalent in at least one eye, excluding those with confounding visual lesions or significant gastrointestinal disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of saffron supplementation on anti-HSP70, hs-CRP, and spirometry test outcomes in patients with allergic asthma.
results_summary: Saffron significantly reduced hs-CRP and anti-HSP70 levels and improved spirometry test results (FEV1, FVC, FEV1/FVC ratio, and FEF 25-75%) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 80 patients (32 women, 48 men) aged 18-65 with mild to moderate allergic asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of crocin (a main constituent of saffron) on reducing inflammation and improving outcomes in patients with refractory diabetic maculopathy.
results_summary: The study found that 15 mg of crocin daily significantly improved HbA1c, central macular thickness, and best-corrected visual acuity compared to placebo, while 5 mg showed clinical but not statistically significant improvements.
population_specificity: 60 patients (101 eyes) with refractory diabetic maculopathy unresponsive to conventional therapy.
effective_dosage: 5 mg or 15 mg crocin tablets per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of saffron supplementation on blood pressure in adults.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation resulted in a small but statistically significant decrease in systolic and diastolic blood pressure, though the effects may not be clinically significant.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether crocin, the active ingredient in saffron, affects serum anti-Hsp27 and hs-CRP levels in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Crocin supplementation led to a 13% reduction in serum anti-Hsp27 titers (not statistically significant) and a significant reduction in hs-CRP levels, though the changes were not significantly different between the crocin and placebo groups. The study concluded that crocin had no significant effect on anti-Hsp27 titers in MetS patients.
population_specificity: Sixty subjects with metabolic syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing studies on saffron and its main constituent crocin to evaluate their potential protective effects against Alzheimer's disease (AD), particularly focusing on their impact on Aβ and tau protein.
results_summary: The review found that crocin exhibits multifunctional protective activities in the brain, including potential improvements in learning and memory, as well as neuroprotective effects, suggesting it could be a promising supplement or drug for AD prevention or treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies on AD and brain injury models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saffron supplementation could prevent delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) and improve biochemical and functional indicators after eccentric exercise.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation significantly reduced creatine kinase (CK) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels, prevented declines in muscle strength, and eliminated perceived pain compared to the control and indomethacin groups.
population_specificity: Nonactive male university students
study_duration: 10 days (1 week before and 3 days after eccentric exercise)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective potential of saffron dietary supplementation in both animal models and early AMD patients, focusing on its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and cell death-regulating properties.
results_summary: Saffron protected photoreceptors from retinal stress in rats, preserving morphology and function, and improved retinal flicker sensitivity in early AMD patients, suggesting neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Rats with light-induced photoreceptor degeneration and human patients with early AMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of saffron supplementation on depressive symptoms in adults with major depressive disorder (MDD) through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Saffron supplementation showed a large effect size in reducing depressive symptoms compared to placebo and was similarly effective as antidepressant medications. The trials were of high quality, with a mean Jadad score of 5.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 and older with symptoms of depression.

study_goal: The researchers were examining whether saffron, as an herbal supplement, could be helpful in managing age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that saffron may be helpful as an adjuvant therapy for ARMD, but no specific outcomes or statistical results are provided.
population_specificity: Patients with age-related macular degeneration (ARMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of saffron and crocin supplementation on hyperlipidaemia and hyperglycaemia in randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: The study found that saffron and crocin supplementation improved lipid profiles, with saffron showing greater reductions in LDL-C and TC levels compared to crocin, but no significant effect on blood glucose levels.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic disorders (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the functional effects of Saffron supplementation in early AMD patients were influenced by CFH and ARMS2 risk genotypes.
results_summary: After three months of Saffron supplementation, fERG amplitude and sensitivity improved significantly compared to baseline, with stable effects throughout follow-up. No differences in improvements were observed across different CFH or ARMS2 genotypes.
population_specificity: Thirty-three early age-related macular degeneration (AMD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Satiereal, a saffron stigma extract, could reduce snacking frequency and enhance satiety, contributing to weight loss in mildly overweight women.
results_summary: Satiereal supplementation led to significantly greater body weight reduction and decreased snacking frequency compared to placebo after 8 weeks, with no reported adverse effects or withdrawals due to the product.
population_specificity: Healthy, mildly overweight women (N = 60).
effective_dosage: 176.5 mg extract per day (1 capsule twice daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Sage, a conjoint treatment for individuals with BPD and their intimate partners, in improving BPD pathology, relationship conflict, and partner mental health.
results_summary: Sage improved self-reported BPD severity, suicidal ideation, emotion dysregulation, and interview-rated frequency of suicidal/self-injurious behaviors, but no changes were observed in relationship outcomes or informant-reported BPD severity and suicidal ideation.
population_specificity: Sixteen couples where one member had BPD and elevated suicidal ideation/chronic and frequent suicidal/self-injurious behavior.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chemical composition, antimicrobial activity, and cytotoxic potential of Salvia aethiopis ethanol extract.
results_summary: The study found that Salvia aethiopis contains bioactive compounds like rosmarinic acid and exhibits potent antibacterial effects against Staphylococcus aureus, Micrococcus luteus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. It also demonstrated dose-dependent cytotoxicity against H-460 non-small cell lung cancer cells, with IC50 values of 80.08 and 56.19 μg/mL after 24 and 48 hours, respectively.
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial and fungal strains, and H-460 non-small cell lung cancer cells.
effective_dosage: IC50 values of 80.08 μg/mL (24h) and 56.19 μg/mL (48h) for cytotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role and impact of Independent SAGE's public scientific advice during the UK's Covid-19 response.
results_summary: The study found that Independent SAGE's public approach to scientific advice provided an alternative model for linking science and politics during emergencies, emphasizing openness, situational adequacy, and addressing practical challenges faced by various groups.
population_specificity: UK public and policymakers during the Covid-19 pandemic.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal LED light treatment strategy for promoting plant growth and polyphenol biosynthesis in S. atropatana and S. bulleyana in vitro cultures.
results_summary: The study found that white LEDs resulted in the highest proliferation rates, while white and mixed red/blue light led to the highest biomass production. Rosmarinic acid levels were highest under red light for S. atropatana and white light for S. bulleyana, with gene expression effects varying by species and light treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro shoot cultures of S. atropatana and S. bulleyana.
effective_dosage: Not specified (light treatments applied, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chemical treatments on the properties of Red Sage Fiber (RSF) and Prosopis Juliflora Fiber (PJF) when incorporated into PLA composites.
results_summary: The study found that chemical treatments significantly improved cellulose content, tensile strength, and crystallinity in RSF and PJF. Treated fibers enhanced the mechanical properties of PLA composites, including increased tensile and flexural strength, and reduced water absorption.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 2-6 wt% NaOH treatment for fibers; 5-15 wt% fiber incorporation in PLA composites.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic effects of a 32% reduced carbohydrate diet (RCHO) on older individuals in a retirement home, focusing on glucose regulation and related biomarkers.
results_summary: The RCHO diet significantly decreased average blood glucose and time spent in hyperglycemia, improved glycated hemoglobin levels, and increased plasma ketones in hyperglycemic participants, demonstrating metabolic benefits. The diet was also confirmed as safe, tolerable, and acceptable in the studied population.
population_specificity: Older individuals (N=24) living in a retirement home.
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary intervention, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the community engagement strategies and outcomes of the BE SAGE program, which combined COVID-19 testing with a garden-based physical activity and nutrition intervention in early care and education centers.
results_summary: The study found that BE SAGE successfully engaged the community through bilingual staffing, online outreach, and partnerships, resulting in 562 participants completing COVID-19 tests and significant online engagement. The program demonstrated effective community involvement and lasting impact.
population_specificity: Early care and education centers with primarily Hispanic/Latino enrollment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics and management of adult patients with moderate-severe ARDS in ICUs across Australia and New Zealand to understand contemporary practice.
results_summary: The study found low compliance with evidence-based practices like lung protective ventilation and prone positioning in ARDS patients, with high use of adjunctive therapies such as systemic steroids and neuromuscular blockers. In-hospital mortality at day 28 was 30.5%.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated adult patients with moderate-severe ARDS in 19 ICUs across Australia and New Zealand.
study_duration: Data collected from enrollment to day 28.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the biosynthetic pathway of salvinorin A (SalA) in Salvia divinorum by assembling a high-quality genome sequence and identifying candidate genes involved in its production.
results_summary: The study successfully assembled a chromosome-level genome of Salvia divinorum, identified two diterpene biosynthetic gene clusters, and pinpointed candidate genes for the remaining steps in the SalA pathway. The genome sequence and gene annotations provide a foundation for further exploration of SalA's clinical potential.
population_specificity: Not applicable (genomic study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict drug-gene associations of extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) in periodontal infections and resistance using graph-based neural networks, including Graph SAGE.
results_summary: Graph SAGE demonstrated high accuracy, precision, recall, and an F1-score of 0.94 in predicting drug-gene associations for ESBLs, outperforming the graph attention network (GAT).
population_specificity: The study focused on drug-gene associations in the context of periodontal infections and antibiotic resistance, not a specific human or animal population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of PCP visits with and without using the self-administered SAGE test in identifying new cognitive disorders in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that using SAGE increased the detection of new cognitive conditions/concerns sixfold (9% vs. 1.5%) and 15-fold when combined with informant reports. Providers using SAGE overwhelmingly (86%) recommended it to colleagues.
population_specificity: Patients aged 65-89 without diagnosed cognitive disorders attending non-acute PCP visits.
study_duration: Not specified (chart reviews conducted 60 days post-visit)

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine how rate control versus rhythm control treatment strategies for atrial fibrillation (AF) affect cognitive function and frailty in older adults.
results_summary: Participants treated with rate control were 1.5 times more likely to experience cognitive impairment over 2 years compared to those treated with rhythm control, but frailty did not differ between the strategies.
population_specificity: Older adults with atrial fibrillation (mean age 75, 49% female, 87% non-Hispanic white).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAGE-324/BIIB124, a GABAA receptor modulator, in reducing essential tremor symptoms compared to placebo.
results_summary: SAGE-324/BIIB124 showed a statistically significant reduction in upper-limb tremor compared to placebo, but common adverse events included somnolence, dizziness, fatigue, and balance disorder. The results support further development of the drug for essential tremor treatment.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 18 to 80 years with essential tremor in the U.S.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using a navigator-based motion compensation technique with five-echo SAGE EPI for quantitative liver BOLD measurements during breath-hold tasks.
results_summary: The study successfully compensated for respiratory motion using a navigator signal, achieving measurable changes in T2 and T2* during breath-hold. Results showed homogeneous distribution of statistical t values and hepatovascular reactivity in healthy volunteers but inhomogeneous patterns in liver carcinoma patients.
population_specificity: Six healthy volunteers and three patients with liver carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between patient-reported outcomes (PROs) and glycemic control in Japanese adults with type 1 diabetes (T1D) across different age groups.
results_summary: The study found that older age groups (≥65 years) had lower hypoglycemia fear and diabetes-related distress, higher insulin treatment satisfaction, and similar quality of life compared to younger groups. Achieving glycemic targets was significantly associated with treatment satisfaction.
population_specificity: Japanese adults with type 1 diabetes (n=528), stratified by age groups (26-44, 45-64, ≥65 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Sage, a 12-session intervention for people with BPD and their intimate partners, targeting BPD severity, relationship conflict, and partner mental health.
results_summary: Four out of five dyads completed Sage, showing improvements in BPD severity, suicidal ideation, and self-injury, while half exhibited reduced conflict. One dyad had poor outcomes.
population_specificity: People with borderline personality disorder (BPD) and their intimate partners, particularly those with frequent suicidal/self-injurious behavior or high suicidal ideation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether catheter ablation (CA) for atrial fibrillation (AF) was associated with lower cognitive impairment compared to medical management in older adults.
results_summary: Participants who underwent CA before enrollment were significantly less likely to develop cognitive impairment over 2 years compared to those managed medically (30.1% vs. 44.8%, p=0.0002). The association remained significant after adjusting for propensity scores (aOR 0.70, 95% CI 0.50-0.97).
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients aged ≥65 with AF, eligible for oral anticoagulation (75.2±6.7 years, 48.6% women, 87.4% white non-Hispanic).
effective_dosage: Not specified (treatment was catheter ablation vs. medical management).

study_goal: The study aimed to determine the effects of sage essential oil (EO) added to milk on growth performance, immune response, ruminal fermentation, and gut microbiota in Holstein calves before weaning.
results_summary: Sage EO increased live weight, feed intake, and daily weight gain, improved immune markers (IgG, reduced proinflammatory cytokines), and altered rumen microbiota and fermentation (reduced NH3-N and T-SCFA). No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Holstein calves (n=24)
effective_dosage: 100 μL or 200 μL of sage EO per calf per day
study_duration: Until weaning stage (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the association of different cardiometabolic multimorbidity combinations with healthcare utilization and quality of life among older adults in Ghana.
results_summary: The study identified four distinct classes of multimorbidity, with the cardiopulmonary and depression class showing higher outpatient visits and hospitalization rates, as well as lower quality of life scores compared to the "healthy class." The cardiometabolic and arthritis class also had higher outpatient visits but no significant association with hospitalization.
population_specificity: Adults aged over 50 years in Ghana.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether catheter ablation (CA) for atrial fibrillation (AF) was associated with lower cognitive impairment compared to medical management in older adults.
results_summary: Participants who underwent CA before enrollment were significantly less likely to develop cognitive impairment over two years compared to those managed medically (30.1% vs. 44.8%, p=0.0002). The adjusted odds ratio (aOR) for cognitive impairment was 0.70 (95% CI 0.50-0.97) favoring CA.
population_specificity: Ambulatory patients aged ≥65 with AF, eligible for oral anticoagulation, predominantly white non-Hispanic (87.4%).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment was catheter ablation or medical management, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of SAGE-718, a novel neuroactive steroid NMDA receptor PAM, on NMDA receptor function and its potential as a treatment for conditions associated with NMDA receptor hypofunction.
results_summary: SAGE-718 potentiated NMDA receptor activity, improved deficits caused by NMDA receptor hypofunction, and showed no epileptiform activity or neurodegeneration. It accelerated the recovery from ketamine-induced effects and ameliorated behavioral and electrophysiological deficits.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, including striatal medium spiny neurons and behavioral models).
study_duration: Chronic dosing was mentioned, but specific duration was not provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Blue Sage water infusion extract (BLS WIE) administered during ischemia and/or reperfusion could provide cardioprotective effects.
results_summary: BLS WIE treatment during reperfusion significantly increased protective signaling molecules (ERK p44, p-Akt, Nrf-2, Bcl-2) and reduced harmful ones (p-p38-MAPK, p-JNK p46, Caspase-3), leading to improved functional recovery and reduced infarct size. The effects were most pronounced when administered post-reperfusion.
population_specificity: Isolated perfused rat hearts subjected to regional ischemia and reperfusion.
study_duration: Treatment was applied for the last 10 minutes of ischemia (PerT) and/or from the onset of reperfusion (PostT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sage essential oil (EO) combined with sous-vide cooking could enhance food safety by inactivating Salmonella enterica in beef tenderloin.
results_summary: Sage EO combined with sous-vide processing at 65 °C for 20 min effectively reduced bacterial counts, including S. enterica, to zero, demonstrating improved food safety. Higher microbial counts were observed at lower temperatures (50 °C for 5 min), but sage EO contributed to stabilization.
population_specificity: Beef tenderloin (musculus psoas major) samples inoculated with S. enterica.
effective_dosage: Not specified (sage EO concentration not detailed).
study_duration: Measurements taken on days 1, 3, and 6 post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Zuranolone (SAGE-217) in individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: Zuranolone demonstrated rapid, clinically meaningful antidepressant effects across multiple randomized clinical trials, with an acceptable level of treatment-emergent adverse events and no serious adverse events leading to discontinuation.
population_specificity: 1662 participants with major depressive disorder (MDD).
effective_dosage: Oral, once-daily, 14-day treatment course (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate factors associated with traditional healer (TH) utilization among older people living with HIV (PLHIV) in South Africa.
results_summary: The study found that 15.89% of older PLHIV utilized TH, primarily due to perceived better healthcare services and flexible payment options. Factors like age, hypertension status, clinic visit frequency, and fruit consumption were significantly associated with TH utilization.
population_specificity: Older people living with HIV (PLHIV) in South Africa (n=516).
study_duration: Data collected between 2011-2013 (specific intervention duration not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of topical Sage (Salvizan) gel versus triamcinolone acetonide gel in treating Recurrent Aphthous Stomatitis (RAS).
results_summary: Salvizan gel significantly outperformed triamcinolone acetonide in pain recovery (1.5 vs. 2.5 days) and wound healing (3.3 vs. 6 days), with no significant difference in patient satisfaction regarding taste or smell.
population_specificity: Sixty patients with minor aphthous ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a fixed combination of Red Ginseng and Red Sage (RG-RS) on gene expression in neuronal cells to evaluate its potential relevance in treating stress, aging-related diseases, and cancer.
results_summary: RG-RS deregulated genes associated with cancer and metastasis, suggesting a predicted decrease in tumorigenesis, tumor cell proliferation, and metastasis, while increasing apoptosis and autophagy. The effects were linked to inhibition of specific signaling and metabolic pathways, including Warburg's aerobic glycolysis and cholesterol biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Murine HT22 hippocampal cell culture

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant, antiproliferative, α-glucosidase inhibitory, and anti-inflammatory activities of Salvia glutinosa extracts.
results_summary: The study found that S. glutinosa extracts exhibited significant α-glucosidase inhibitory activity, modest cytotoxic effects on HepG2 cells, and in vivo anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects, supporting its traditional use.
population_specificity: Rat model of induced inflammation (turpentine oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate SAGE-718, an NMDAR PAM, as a potential treatment for cognitive impairment in Huntington's disease.
results_summary: SAGE-718 was identified as a potent NMDAR PAM with optimized pharmacokinetics for oral dosing. It has completed phase 1 trials and is undergoing phase 2 trials for cognitive impairment in Huntington's disease.
population_specificity: Patients with cognitive impairment in Huntington's disease (phase 2 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the predictive accuracy of three risk prediction models (PAGE-B, SAGE-B, and CAGE-B) for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development after 5 years of antiviral therapy (AVT) in patients with chronic hepatitis B (CHB).
results_summary: The SAGE-B and CAGE-B models showed significantly higher predictive accuracy (AUROC 0.772-0.844 and 0.785-0.838, respectively) compared to the PAGE-B model (AUROC 0.696-0.745) for HCC development after 5 years of entecavir treatment. All three models independently predicted HCC development, with high-risk groups showing significantly higher risk.
population_specificity: 1,335 patients with chronic hepatitis B who initiated entecavir treatment between 2006 and 2011 and were followed for over 5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine cost-reducing behaviors (CRBs), cost-related medication nonadherence, and spending less on basic needs among older adults with atrial fibrillation (AF).
results_summary: The study found that 69% of participants engaged in CRBs, while 4% reported cost-related medication nonadherence and 6% spent less on basic needs to afford medications. Factors like cognitive impairment, marital status, income, and comorbidities influenced CRB engagement.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with atrial fibrillation and high stroke risk (CHA2DS2VASc ≥ 2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sage extract, alone and in combination with enterocin 7420, on the quality and mineral content of rabbit meat.
results_summary: Sage extract increased iron, phosphorus, and zinc levels in rabbit meat while reducing calcium and manganese. The physico-chemical traits of the meat were not negatively affected by the treatment.
population_specificity: 96 Hyla rabbits aged 35 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different irrigation regimes and fertilizer sources (including TiO2 nanoparticles and AMF) on the essential oil (EO) quantity, quality, and yield of sage under drought stress conditions.
results_summary: Moderate and severe drought stress reduced sage dry matter yield by 30% and 65%, respectively, while the co-addition of TiO2 and AMF increased yield and water use efficiency by 35%. The highest EO content, yield, and cis-thujone levels were achieved under moderate drought stress with TiO2 + AMF fertilization, and net income improved significantly with these treatments.
population_specificity: Sage plants (Salvia officinalis L.) grown under controlled field conditions with varying irrigation and fertilization regimes.
effective_dosage: TiO2 nanoparticles (100 mg L-1), AMF inoculation, and co-addition of TiO2 + AMF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if SAGE could reduce periodontal inflammation and alveolar bone loss in a beagle dog model of periodontitis as a surrogate for human periodontitis.
results_summary: SAGE treatment significantly reduced gingival inflammation, pocket depth, clinical attachment loss, and alveolar bone loss, while also lowering inflammatory mediators and cell-signaling molecules associated with periodontitis.
population_specificity: Adult female beagle dogs with generalized periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of wild sage metabolites (WSM) for snoring treatment and alpha wave activation in healthy adults.
results_summary: WSM consumption reduced the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) global score by 29%, improved sleep mate assessments, and increased alpha brain waves by 55%. The study concluded that WSM significantly reduced snoring, stress, and improved sleep quality with good tolerance and no reported side effects.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women compliant with inclusion criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate habitat selection by greater sage-grouse after a wildfire and evaluate their responses to post-fire restoration treatments, including herbicide application and seeding.
results_summary: Sage-grouse avoided areas with high exotic annual grass cover but selected for recovering sagebrush and perennial grasses, especially high-density sagebrush by the third year post-fire. They also preferred areas treated with herbicide and seeded with sagebrush, grasses, and forbs, though responses varied over time.
population_specificity: Male greater sage-grouse in a sagebrush steppe ecosystem in Idaho and Oregon.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how age, geriatric factors, and medical comorbidities influence the choice between rhythm and rate control strategies in older adults with atrial fibrillation (AF).
results_summary: Older age, cognitive impairment, and peripheral vascular disease were associated with a rate control strategy, while visual impairment, congestive heart failure, and anticoagulation use were linked to a rhythm control strategy. There was no difference in health-related quality of life between the two treatment groups.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥65 years with AF, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2, and eligible for anticoagulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the occurrence, clinical manifestations, and outcomes of systemic arterial gas embolism (SAGE) following bronchoscopic lung biopsy procedures.
results_summary: The study found that SAGE is a rare but severe complication of bronchoscopic biopsies, often presenting with acute neurologic or cardiac symptoms and associated with high mortality (28%) and residual neurologic deficits (24%). Cases occurred under various ventilation conditions and biopsy types.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent bronchoscopic lung biopsy procedures and experienced SAGE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sage essential oils (EOs) on maintaining tomato fruit quality during storage and transportation, focusing on firmness, respiration rates, ethylene emission, and antioxidant metabolism.
results_summary: Sage EOs retained fruit firmness and reduced weight loss in breaker tomatoes at low concentrations (50 μL L-1), while higher concentrations (500 μL L-1) accelerated metabolism. Red tomatoes showed earlier effects, including increased respiration, ethylene, and β-carotene, with decreased lycopene. Organoleptic trials favored EO-treated red fruit.
population_specificity: Tomato fruits (Solanum lycopersicum L. cv. Dafni) at breaker and red ripening stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Sage oil nanoemulsion in wound healing using a rat model.
results_summary: The study found that Sage oil nanoemulsion significantly increased collagen content (77.52%) and tensile strength (56.20%), reduced epithelialization period (42.85%), and demonstrated notable antimicrobial activity compared to control.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the link between nine potentially modifiable risk factors (including less education, hearing impairment, depression, physical inactivity, hypertension, obesity, smoking, diabetes, and social isolation) and dementia in India, to inform public health interventions.
results_summary: Less education, hearing impairment, depression, and physical inactivity were associated with lower cognitive scores and increased odds of dementia, while obesity was associated with higher cognitive scores and lower odds of dementia. Social isolation was linked to lower cognitive scores but decreased odds of dementia, and results for smoking, diabetes, and hypertension were inconsistent.
population_specificity: Older adults in India (from three studies: 10/66 Dementia Study, Longitudinal Aging Study of India, and Study of Global Ageing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether non-White atrial fibrillation (AF) patients exhibit accelerated biological aging compared to White AF patients and whether this aging is associated with cognitive functioning.
results_summary: Non-White AF patients had 2.9 years more accelerated biological aging than White patients, and higher accelerated aging was associated with lower cognitive scores, with a stronger negative association observed in non-White patients.
population_specificity: 974 participants with atrial fibrillation from ambulatory care practices in Massachusetts and Georgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the underestimation of bleeding risk among older atrial fibrillation patients on oral anticoagulant therapy and identify associated characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that 68% of participants underestimated their bleeding risk, with non-White individuals and women less likely to underestimate risk, while those with a history of bleeding or certain comorbidities were more likely to underestimate it.
population_specificity: Patients aged ≥65 years with atrial fibrillation, a CHA2DS2-VASc risk score ≥2, and on oral anticoagulant therapy.

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of single zuranolone (SAGE-217) doses (30 mg and 45 mg) on sleep measures in a phase advance insomnia model in healthy adults.
results_summary: Zuranolone significantly improved sleep efficiency, wake after sleep onset, duration of awakenings, and total sleep time compared to placebo, with subjective sleep measures also showing improvement. The drug was generally well tolerated, with headache and fatigue being the most common adverse events.
population_specificity: Healthy adults
study_duration: Three treatment periods (crossover design, exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how salicylic acid (SA) and calcium chloride (CaCl2) affect the heat tolerance, physiology, and morphology of two sage species (S. elegans and S. officinalis) under high-temperature stress.
results_summary: Combined treatment of 100 μM SA and 5 mM CaCl2 improved heat tolerance in S. officinalis, enhancing SPAD, NDVI, and Fv/Fm values while reducing leaf damage (RI%). S. officinalis showed better resilience than S. elegans under combined treatments.
population_specificity: Potted sage plants (S. elegans and S. officinalis) exposed to high-temperature stress.
effective_dosage: SA (100 μM) and CaCl2 (5 mM), applied once before heat stress.
study_duration: Heat stress exposure for 30 minutes, followed by 3-day evaluation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of non-native plant removal and precipitation on the post-fire recovery of Artemisia californica in southern California sage scrub habitats.
results_summary: The study found that higher spring precipitation increased survival of both adult and seedling Artemisia californica, while non-native plant removal significantly reduced non-native cover, improved seedling survival, and increased canopy area of native shrubs. Almost all A. californica established post-fire from seedlings, with limited crown resprouting.
population_specificity: Southern California sage scrub fragment post-fire environment.
study_duration: 7 years of monitoring (4 years with experimental non-native removal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the predictive performance of the CAGE-B and SAGE-B models for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) development in Asian patients with chronic hepatitis B (CHB) undergoing antiviral therapy.
results_summary: Both SAGE-B and CAGE-B models showed acceptable performance in predicting HCC after 5 years of antiviral therapy, with SAGE-B demonstrating slightly better predictive accuracy (higher AUROCs and likelihood ratios) compared to CAGE-B. The cumulative incidence of HCC was significantly higher in high-risk groups identified by both models.
population_specificity: Asian patients with chronic hepatitis B (CHB) undergoing sustained antiviral therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on predictive models, not dosage).
study_duration: More than 5 years of follow-up after antiviral therapy initiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between glycaemic control and patient-reported outcomes (PROs) in adults with type 1 diabetes across different age groups and regions.
results_summary: The study found that better glycaemic control (HbA1c <7% or individualised targets) was associated with lower diabetes-related emotional distress, less hypoglycaemia fear, higher insulin treatment satisfaction, and improved quality of life. Results were generally consistent across age groups but showed some regional variability.
population_specificity: Adults with type 1 diabetes, stratified by age groups (26-44, 45-64, and ≥65 years) and regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the genetic diversity, population structure, and intra/inter-specific differentiation of wild Salvia miltiorrhiza and its related species (S. bowleyana and S. paramiltiorrhiza) to inform conservation and breeding efforts.
results_summary: The study found high genetic diversity in S. miltiorrhiza (π = 0.0788, H e = 0.0783 ± 0.0007), identified two major lineage groups, and suggested Dabie Mountain as a genetic diversity center. It also indicated potential genetic exchange/hybridization between S. miltiorrhiza and its relatives.
population_specificity: Wild populations of Salvia miltiorrhiza, S. bowleyana, and S. paramiltiorrhiza from 23 locations in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the predictive performance of CAGE-B and SAGE-B scores for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) risk among Asian chronic hepatitis B (CHB) patients undergoing long-term antiviral therapy.
results_summary: CAGE-B and SAGE-B scores showed acceptable predictive performances for HCC risk, with CAGE-B outperforming SAGE-B and other conventional models. Both scores demonstrated significant stratification of HCC risk across different score ranges.
population_specificity: Asian CHB patients with well-controlled viremia (serum HBV DNA < 2000 IU/mL) receiving antiviral therapy, excluding those with decompensated cirrhosis or HCC at baseline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether the SAGE Program could foster earlier and more comprehensive serious illness conversations for hospitalized older adults.
results_summary: The SAGE intervention significantly increased the frequency, earlier timing, and quality of serious illness conversations compared to the control group, with 89.1% of intervention patients having documented conversations versus 26.1% in the comparison group.
population_specificity: Older adults admitted to a general medicine service at Brigham & Women's Hospital in Boston, Massachusetts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term (5-year) safety, efficacy, and real-world outcomes of transcervical fibroid ablation (TFA) using the Sonata system for treating symptomatic uterine fibroids.
results_summary: Preliminary results from the SAGE registry indicate TFA has an excellent safety profile (0.6% device-related and procedure-related adverse event rates) and broad applicability across fibroid types and sizes, with significant symptom relief and improved quality of life. The study also reports durable outcomes, including low surgical reintervention rates.
population_specificity: Women with symptomatic uterine fibroids (up to 500 participants across 50 global sites).

study_goal: The researchers investigated changes in blood pressure and hypertension awareness over 11-12 years in older adults in Ghana using data from the WHO-SAGE study.
results_summary: The study found no significant change in systolic blood pressure, a decrease in diastolic blood pressure, and an increase in pulse pressure. Hypertension awareness improved, but treatment rates and control remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50 years and older in Ghana (n = 820).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify seasonal habitat selection patterns of greater sage-grouse in Utah to inform conservation planning at a finer scale within the species' southern range.
results_summary: Sage-grouse preferred areas with greater sagebrush cover, higher elevations, and gentler slopes while avoiding lower precipitation and higher temperatures. Anthropogenic factors previously linked to range-wide distribution were not significant predictors at this scale.
population_specificity: Greater sage-grouse (Centrocercus urophasianus) in Utah.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute and sub-chronic toxicity of a mixture of essential oils from Cretan herbs, including Greek sage, to assess its safety for human consumption.
results_summary: The study found no toxicity in rats for the essential oil mixture (CAPeo) containing Greek sage, thyme, and Cretan dittany, supporting its safety. Additionally, previous research indicated significant antiviral properties and symptom reduction in upper respiratory tract infections.
population_specificity: Rats (for toxicity evaluation); humans with upper respiratory tract infections (in prior clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate zuranolone's potential as a neuroactive steroid GABAA receptor positive allosteric modulator with drug-like properties and CNS exposure in preclinical models, and its therapeutic promise for mood disorders.
results_summary: Zuranolone demonstrated potent activity in modulating GABAA receptors, showing efficacy in preclinical models by protecting against chemo-convulsant seizures and enhancing EEG β-frequency power. It exhibited synergistic effects with diazepam and sustained increases in GABA currents, supporting its potential for treating mood disorders.
population_specificity: Preclinical models (mice and rats)
interactions: Synergistic effect with diazepam noted at synaptic receptors

study_goal: To examine the feasibility of remote monitoring of physical, cognitive, and psychosocial status in older adults with atrial fibrillation using a smartphone app and wearable activity monitor.
results_summary: The study found that it was feasible to use a mobile health app and wearable device for serial geriatric assessments in older AF patients over 6 months, with moderate adherence rates (52% for app-based assessments and 28% for walk tests at 6 months). No differences in demographic or clinical factors were observed between completers and non-completers.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 71, range 65-86) with atrial fibrillation and eligible for anticoagulation therapy (CHA2DS2VASc ≥2).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (no dosage mentioned, as the study focused on app and wearable use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of Common Sage (CS) extracts for treating dysbiotic disorders in rats with experimental infectious colitis.
results_summary: The study found that CS extracts showed an antagonistic effect on pathogenic microorganisms without inhibiting normal gut microbiota, suggesting potential efficacy for correcting dysbiotic disorders. The effects were comparable to the antibiotic rifaximin but without harming beneficial bacteria.
population_specificity: Rats with experimentally induced dysbiotic disorders (infectious colitis).
effective_dosage: 50% CS extract, complex of CS phenolic compounds with L-lysine (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the expression of cancer testis antigens, including SAGE, across various tumor types to assess their potential as targets for cancer immunotherapy.
results_summary: SAGE was expressed in 21.8% of tumor samples, with higher rates in prostate (35.3%), oesophageal (32.9%), and ovarian (26.3%) cancers. Oesophageal cancer showed the highest frequency of SAGE expression among the studied tumor types.
population_specificity: 585 tumor samples across 21 tumor types, with oesophageal cancer being the most common.
study_duration: Data collected between June 2009 and March 2018 (retrospective analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with underestimation of stroke risk among older patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and relate this to oral anticoagulation (OAC) use.
results_summary: A significant proportion of participants misperceived their stroke risk, with 46% of high-risk patients underestimating their risk. Older patients were more likely to underestimate risk, while those on OAC were less likely to do so.
population_specificity: Older patients (>65 years) with non-valvular AF and a CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate glycaemic control and diabetes management in adults with type 1 diabetes (T1DM) across different age groups and regions.
results_summary: The study found that only 24.3% of participants achieved the glycaemic target (HbA1c <7.0%), with higher success in younger age groups (26-44 years) and regional variations (highest in Europe, lowest in the Middle East). Hypoglycaemia and severe hyperglycaemia incidence decreased with age, and therapeutic management varied by age and region.
population_specificity: Adults with type 1 diabetes (ages 26-44, 45-64, and ≥65 years) across multiple global regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sage tea on oxidative status, lipid profile, and insulin resistance in rats with testosterone-induced PCOS.
results_summary: Sage tea increased total antioxidant capacity (TAC) and reduced HDL-C, glucose, total cholesterol, LDL-C, and atherogenic index levels, but did not affect MDA, insulin, total triglycerides, or VLDL-C. The findings suggest potential cardiovascular protective effects in PCOS.
population_specificity: Immature female Wistar rats (21-day old) with testosterone-induced PCOS.
effective_dosage: Sage tea administered as a replacement for water (exact concentration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence of psychosocial/cognitive multimorbidity (depression, anxiety, cognitive impairment) in older adults with atrial fibrillation (AF) and its association with health-related quality of life (HRQoL) and symptom burden.
results_summary: Approximately 35% of participants had one impairment, 17% had two, and 8% had three; those with multiple impairments had significantly higher odds of poor HRQoL and high symptom burden compared to those with no impairments.
population_specificity: Older adults (≥65 years) with AF, CHA2DS2VASC risk score ≥ 2, eligible for oral anticoagulation therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with vitamin D or omega-3 fatty acids reduces pain, alters pain medication usage, or improves quality of life in young women with endometriosis.
results_summary: Vitamin D supplementation showed significant improvement in pain scores, but the effect was similar to placebo. Fish oil (omega-3) supplementation resulted in a more modest pain reduction, and neither intervention was statistically superior to placebo.
population_specificity: Young women (aged 12-25 years) with surgically confirmed endometriosis and pelvic pain.
effective_dosage: 2000 IU vitamin D3 daily or 1000 mg fish oil daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioactive compounds in sea buckthorn and evaluate their efficacy in treating metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn demonstrated positive effects on metabolic syndrome symptoms, including reduced blood lipid content, blood pressure, and blood sugar levels, and regulation of key metabolites. The study highlighted bioactive compounds from different tissues of the plant and their mechanisms of action.
population_specificity: Cell lines, animal models, and human patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms by which Hippophae rhamnoides L. polysaccharide I (HRPI) improves cognitive impairment in mice with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: HRPI improved memory and cognition, reduced Aβ peptide deposition and neuronal necrosis, decreased inflammatory markers (TLR4, MyD88, TNFα, IL-6), and modulated oxidative stress pathways (KEAP1/Nrf2, SOD, GSH-Px) in AD mice.
population_specificity: Mice with Alzheimer's disease (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of daily consumption of sea buckthorn juice on cardiovascular disease risk factors in women with hypercholesterolemia.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in body weight, body fat, visceral fat, LDL cholesterol, and inflammatory markers (CRP, immunoglobulins), along with an increase in HDL cholesterol after 8 weeks of sea buckthorn juice consumption.
population_specificity: 19 women with hypercholesterolemia, mean age 54.06 ± 2.97 years.
effective_dosage: 50 mL of 100% sea buckthorn juice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if enzymatic treatment of sea buckthorn pomace could reduce acrylamide formation in biscuits while maintaining nutritional value.
results_summary: Enzymatic treatment with asparaginase reduced asparagine content by 95% (from 1834 mg/kg to 89 mg/kg) in dried sea buckthorn pomace. Substituting 10% of flour with treated pomace reduced acrylamide content by 35-64% in biscuits compared to untreated pomace.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or food product study, no human participants mentioned).
effective_dosage: 10% substitution of wholegrain cereal flour with enzymatically treated sea buckthorn pomace powder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare different sample preparation methods (centrifugation and filtration) for determining total phenolic content (TPC) and antioxidant activity in sea buckthorn juice.
results_summary: Centrifugation or membrane treatment affected TPC and antioxidant activity measurements. Method (N) (filtering the reaction solution post-assay) showed the least loss of TPC and antioxidant activity and was recommended for assays. TPC and antioxidant activity correlated positively and followed similar trends over fermentation time.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on sea buckthorn juice).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on method comparison, not intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of sea buckthorn extract (SBE) supplementation on production performance, egg quality, cholesterol deposition, serum biochemistry, and immune markers in laying ducks.
results_summary: SBE supplementation at 1.0 g/kg significantly improved egg weight, feed conversion ratio, yolk weight, shell strength, and amino acid content while reducing yolk cholesterol and blood lipids. It also enhanced antioxidant capacity and immune markers in laying ducks.
population_specificity: 240 female laying ducks aged 23 weeks with similar body weight.
effective_dosage: 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 g/kg of SBE in diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antifatigue effects of sea buckthorn seed oil (SSO) in mice and explore its potential mechanisms related to oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurotransmitter regulation.
results_summary: SSO increased swimming endurance, reduced markers of fatigue (lactic acid, blood urea nitrogen), improved antioxidant activity (superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase), and modulated inflammatory and neurotransmitter pathways (dopamine, 5-hydroxytryptamine, NLRP3 inflammasome).
population_specificity: Mice subjected to exercise-induced fatigue.
effective_dosage: 0.85, 1.68, and 3.35 g/kg body weight (low, medium, high doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of different preservation technologies (PEF, HPP, OH, and thermal treatment) on the quality characteristics and microbial safety of sea buckthorn syrup.
results_summary: The study found that all tested preservation technologies maintained microbial stability over 8 weeks of storage at 4°C, with similar impacts on nutrient content (ascorbic acid, antioxidant activity, phenolic compounds, tocopherols). HPP-treated samples retained more fresh-like color and taste, while PEF and HPP syrups showed continued enzyme activity during storage.
population_specificity: Not specified (study focused on sea buckthorn syrup samples).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study analyzed processed syrup, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of sea buckthorn polysaccharide (SBP) on cognitive dysfunction induced by a high-fat diet in mice and explore its biological mechanisms.
results_summary: SBP alleviated cognitive dysfunction by inhibiting neuroinflammation via the NF-κB pathway and improving synaptic function via the CREB/BDNF/TrkB pathway. It also improved gut barrier integrity and reduced inflammation by modulating gut microbiota.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the phytochemical content and biological activity of sea buckthorn seeds, focusing on their antioxidant and anticoagulant effects in vitro.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn seeds contained diverse flavonoids and bioactive compounds. Both extracts inhibited lipid peroxidation and protein carbonylation, with the roasted seed extract also reducing oxidation of thiol groups and prolonging white thrombus formation at the highest concentration (50 µg/mL).
population_specificity: In vitro study (plasma samples)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the phytochemistry, nutrients, health benefits, and food applications of sea buckthorn.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn contains numerous bioactive components and exhibits various health benefits, including antioxidant, anticancer, anti-inflammatory, and hepatoprotective activities. It has potential as a functional food or dietary supplement for chronic disease prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of using different parts of sea buckthorn as a natural source of serotonin and to determine optimal extraction methods.
results_summary: The study found that one- and two-year-old woody shoots of sea buckthorn were the best sources of serotonin, with content varying significantly by season (10-fold difference between summer and winter). Optimal extraction was achieved using mechanochemical treatment and drying at 60-80°C.
population_specificity: Sea buckthorn plants (Hippophae rhamnoides L.) from different regions and varieties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different heat-treatment methods affect the flavonoid composition, taste, color, and antioxidant activity of sea buckthorn pulp.
results_summary: Heat treatment increased extractable flavonoids, altered taste properties (enhanced bitterness and acidity, reduced saltiness, umami, and sweetness), and improved antioxidant capacity, which correlated with flavonoid monomer content. High-temperature, high-pressure treatment yielded the highest flavonoid content (3.66 ± 0.21 mg/ml).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on sea buckthorn pulp)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented sea buckthorn juice (FHJ) improves physiological activity, probiotic availability, and mitigates metabolic syndrome (MS) compared to non-fermented juice (BHJ).
results_summary: FHJ demonstrated superior antioxidant and antidiabetic effects in vitro and improved hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance, and oxidative stress in mice with diet-induced MS. It also restored microbial diversity, modulated obesogenic bacteria, and increased short-chain fatty acids linked to MS amelioration.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal fermentation process for sea buckthorn juice using probiotics and evaluate its antioxidant and antimicrobial effects.
results_summary: Fermented sea buckthorn juice showed increased biological enzyme activity, total flavonoid content, and strong antimicrobial effects against E. coli, S. aureus, and B. cinerea. It also demonstrated antioxidant capacity by enhancing SOD and GSH-Px activities while reducing ROS, CAT activity, and MDA content in oxidative stress-induced C2C12 cells.
population_specificity: In vitro (C2C12 cells) and microbial assays (E. coli, S. aureus, B. cinerea).
effective_dosage: 4.08 × 10^6 CFU/mL bacterial inoculation, 2.98% (w/v) sugar, 20 h fermentation at 37°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary sea buckthorn leaves (SBL) and Chromium on the nutritional quality and oxidative stability of chicken meat.
results_summary: SBL and Chromium supplementation improved the fatty acid profile, increased antioxidant capacity, and enhanced oxidative stability in chicken meat, lowering TBARS levels after storage. The treatment also increased concentrations of beneficial compounds like lutein, zeaxanthin, Fe, and Zn.
population_specificity: Cobb 500 chickens (n=90)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sea Buckthorn enhances the efficacy of QGY in treating osteoporosis by inhibiting CKIP-1 and Notum expression via the Wnt/β-catenin pathway and to identify its active components.
results_summary: Sea Buckthorn improved bone morphometric parameters, increased estrogen levels, and activated the Wnt/β-catenin pathway, with enhanced effects when combined with QGY or Eucommia ulmoides. Seven small molecules in SBT were identified as potential active ingredients targeting CKIP-1 and Notum.
population_specificity: PMOP (postmenopausal osteoporosis) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of sea buckthorn and metformin on diabetes-related parameters in Zucker diabetic fatty rats, as well as characterize its bioactive compounds and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn treatment suppressed hyperglycemia, reduced water intake, and decreased sorbitol levels in the lens of the eyes. Dry berries had significantly higher bioactive compounds and antioxidant capacity compared to fresh berries.
population_specificity: Zucker diabetic fatty rats (animal model of type 2 Diabetes mellitus)
effective_dosage: 500 and 1000 mg/kg body weight of sea buckthorn, and combinations with 150 mg/kg body weight of metformin

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the potential of Sea Buckthorn (H. rhamnoides) for treating osteoporosis by evaluating its osteogenic differentiation-promoting effects in ovariectomized mice.
results_summary: The study found that Sea Buckthorn extracts (EHRF, HRH, and HRHF4) significantly stimulated osteoblast differentiation in mesenchymal stem cells and increased bone mineral density in osteoporosis-induced mice, with HRHF4 showing the most pronounced effect. The active fractions also restored osteogenic gene expression in mouse tibia.
population_specificity: 9-week-old female ICR mice with induced osteoporosis via ovariectomy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (oral administration of HRH and HRHF4 fractions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sea buckthorn supplementation affects factors related to metabolic syndrome, particularly lipid metabolism, blood sugar, blood pressure, and BMI.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn supplementation significantly improved lipid profiles (reducing triglycerides, total cholesterol, and LDL cholesterol while increasing HDL cholesterol) in subjects with abnormal lipid metabolism but had no effect on blood sugar, blood pressure, or BMI. The study noted high heterogeneity as a limitation.
population_specificity: Subjects with and without abnormal lipid metabolism (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-platelet and anticoagulant potential of isorhamnetin and its derivatives isolated from sea buckthorn fruit in human blood platelets and whole blood.
results_summary: The study found that the tested phenolic compounds (50 µg/mL) significantly reduced platelet aggregation and demonstrated anti-adhesive activity, with compound 2 showing more intense effects than isorhamnetin. The mechanism of action may involve binding to various platelet receptors, but further studies are needed.
population_specificity: Human washed blood platelets and human whole blood in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of sea buckthorn berry puree on plasma metabolomics and gut microbiota in hypercholesterolemic subjects.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn berry puree altered plasma metabolic profiles, improved energy metabolism markers (e.g., glucose, lactate, creatine), and enriched beneficial gut bacteria (e.g., butyrate-producers, Prevotella, Faecalibacterium) while reducing harmful bacteria (e.g., Parasutterella). Effects peaked at 45 days but showed some regression by 90 days.
population_specificity: 56 hypercholesterolemic subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the composition and potential of sea buckthorn twigs as a source of valuable biologically active substances for applications in food, nutraceuticals, and cosmetics.
results_summary: The study found that sea buckthorn twigs, particularly from the 'Maria Bruvele' cultivar, yielded high levels of polyphenolic compounds and serotonin. The hydrophilic extracts demonstrated radical scavenging activity, antibacterial/antifungal effects, and enzymatic activity relevant for treating underweight and malabsorption conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether topical application of Sea Buckthorn flavonoids (TFH) could improve atopic dermatitis (AD)-like lesions in mice by reducing inflammation and restoring skin barrier function.
results_summary: TFH significantly improved dermatitis severity by reducing inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-4, IFN-γ, TSLP), increasing filaggrin expression, and inhibiting key inflammatory pathways (NF-κB, ERK, P38) in both mouse skin and human keratinocytes.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with MC903-induced AD-like lesions and IFN-γ/TNF-α-treated HaCaT cells (human keratinocytes).
effective_dosage: 0.5% and 1% TFH cream applied topically once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of sea buckthorn preparations on hemostasis and their potential role in treating and preventing cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study found that sea buckthorn preparations, including extracts and fractions, positively impact hemostasis and show cardioprotective potential, with significant anti-cancer, anti-ulcer, hepatoprotective, antibacterial, and antiviral properties.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining ball milling and cellulase treatment could improve the texture and hypoglycemic properties of sea buckthorn insoluble dietary fiber (IDF).
results_summary: The combined modification method significantly improved the physicochemical and functional properties of IDF, including water-holding, oil-binding, and swelling capacities, as well as enhanced glucose adsorption, diffusion inhibition, and α-amylase activity inhibition.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ozonation on the quality, microbial load, and storage life of sea buckthorn berries.
results_summary: Ozonation significantly reduced microbial load (aerobic bacteria by 3 log cfu g-1, yeast and mold by 1 log cfu g-1) and water loss during storage, while having negligible immediate impact on weight and moisture. The highest ozone dose (100 ppm for 30 min) was most effective in preserving quality.
population_specificity: Sea buckthorn berries (Hippophae rhamnoides L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of Sea Buckthorn's nutritional value, health benefits, and applications based on current knowledge.
results_summary: The study highlights Sea Buckthorn's rich chemical composition and versatile health benefits, supporting its use in preventing and treating diet-related diseases. It emphasizes the plant's economic advantages and historical significance in natural medicine.
population_specificity: Not specified (general overview)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an eco-friendly extraction method (MCAE) for sea buckthorn pomaces to enhance flavonoid yield and evaluate its hepatoprotective effects.
results_summary: The MCAE method doubled flavonoid yield (26.82 ± 0.53 mg/g) compared to traditional methods and significantly improved biomarkers in NAFLD mice, demonstrating hepatoprotective activity.
population_specificity: Mice with tetracycline-induced liver injury (NAFLD model).
effective_dosage: Not specified for animal intervention. Extraction conditions: 40% Na2CO3, 29:1 ball-to-material ratio, 410 rpm, 24 min milling, 25 °C, 20 min extraction, 1:10 solid-to-solution ratio.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wound healing period of second-degree burns treated with sea buckthorn cream versus 1% silver sulfadiazine (SSD) dressings.
results_summary: The study found that sea buckthorn cream significantly reduced the healing time of second-degree burns compared to 1% SSD (p < 0.001), demonstrating greater clinical efficacy. The results suggest sea buckthorn can shorten treatment duration and reduce healthcare burdens.
population_specificity: 55 patients with second-degree burns in a hospital in Isfahan, Iran.
study_duration: Until complete wound healing was attained

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map the m6A methylation patterns in sea buckthorn transcriptome and investigate its role in drought stress response.
results_summary: The study identified m6A methylation sites in sea buckthorn, showing enrichment near stop codons and 3'UTRs, and linked these modifications to metabolic biosynthesis. Drought stress led to 13,287 differential m6A peaks, with demethylase genes upregulated, suggesting m6A's role in stress adaptation.
population_specificity: Sea buckthorn (Hippophae rhamnoides Linn.) plants under drought and control conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sea buckthorn fruit puree (SBFP) could improve glucose regulation in individuals with impaired glucose regulation (IGR).
results_summary: SBFP consumption for five weeks led to a slight but statistically significant reduction in fasting plasma glucose (FPG) compared to placebo, though no significant effects were observed on glycated serum protein (GSP) or postprandial glucose (2 h PG-AUC). The placebo group showed a small increase in FPG, highlighting a modest beneficial effect of SBFP.
population_specificity: 38 subjects with impaired glucose regulation (IGR).
effective_dosage: 90 mL/day of sea buckthorn fruit puree (SBFP).
study_duration: Five weeks of intervention, followed by a four-week washout, then another five weeks of placebo or vice versa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cytotoxic, antioxidant, anti-platelet, and anticoagulant effects of a saponin fraction from sea buckthorn leaves on HL-60 cancer cells and oxidative stress.
results_summary: The saponin fraction reduced HL-60 cell viability at higher concentrations (≥50 µg/mL) and induced apoptosis at 100 µg/mL, while lower concentrations (0.5–1 µg/mL) stimulated cell viability. It also reduced oxidative DNA damage but increased free radicals at high H2O2 levels and showed anticoagulant potential at 50 µg/mL.
population_specificity: HL-60 cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cytotoxicity, genotoxicity, and pro-apoptotic properties of low-polarity fractions from sea-buckthorn in human tumor and normal cells.
results_summary: Low-polarity fractions from sea-buckthorn showed cytotoxic effects, being 3 times more potent in cancer cells than normal cells, and induced apoptosis via caspase 3/7 activation. High concentrations exhibited moderate genotoxicity, suggesting potential for supporting cancer cell elimination.
population_specificity: Human tumor and normal cells cultured in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the chemical composition, nutritional and health effects, and toxicological properties of Sea Buckthorn to assess its potential for treating human diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Sea Buckthorn contains a unique mixture of bioactive compounds with various biological activities, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anti-cancer, and protective effects for multiple organs. Toxicological results indicated no toxicity in the fruits or seeds.
population_specificity: Cell lines, animals, patients, and healthy volunteers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of brassinosteroid (BR) and the gene HrCYP90B1 in enhancing sea buckthorn's resistance to the sea buckthorn fruit fly (RBO).
results_summary: The study found that BR treatment reduced fruit damage rates from RBO infection and identified HrCYP90B1 as a key gene regulating BR and salicylic acid (SA) levels, which improved resistance. Silencing HrCYP90B1 increased susceptibility to RBO by altering hormone pathways.
population_specificity: Sea buckthorn fruits (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sea Buckthorn (HRP) protects the liver by regulating CYP3A enzyme pathways and inhibiting NF-κB signaling in rats with immune liver injury.
results_summary: HRP reversed CYP3A down-regulation and reduced inflammatory markers (NF-κB, IL-1β, TNF-α, iNOS) in a dose-dependent manner, partially alleviating liver injury. The effect was linked to transcriptional, translational, and post-translational regulation of enzymes.
population_specificity: Rats with immune liver injury induced by BCG.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of sea buckthorn puree consumption on reducing blood lipid and other risk factors of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in hypercholesterolemic patients.
results_summary: Sea buckthorn puree did not affect serum total cholesterol, LDL-C, or triglyceride levels but temporarily decreased HDL-C before increasing it. It moderately reduced hsCRP concentration and diastolic blood pressure, showing anti-inflammatory and anti-hypertensive effects without impacting lipid markers.
population_specificity: 111 patients with hypercholesterolemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant potential and response to free radicals of Sea Buckthorn in hyperlipidemic rats treated with atorvastatin, as well as its effects on organ cytoarchitecture.
results_summary: Sea Buckthorn significantly reduced oxidative stress in the heart, liver, and kidney (p < 0.001) and improved liver and kidney cytoarchitecture, particularly when combined with atorvastatin. The combination showed better cell regeneration compared to high-fat diet controls.
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemic Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Sea Buckthorn oil on atopic dermatitis (AD) in a mouse model induced by DNCB, focusing on skin barrier function, immune response modulation, and Langerhans cell activity.
results_summary: Sea Buckthorn oil reduced dermatitis scores, ear thickness, mast cell infiltration, lymph node weight, and Th2 cell activity. It also lowered inflammatory cytokine expression (IL-4, IFN-γ, TNF-α, TSLP), serum IgE levels, and inhibited Langerhans cell migration and maturation.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 5 ml/kg and 10 ml/kg, administered daily by gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sea Buckthorn flavonoids (SFs) could prevent cognitive impairments and metabolic complications induced by a high-fat and high-fructose diet in obese mice.
results_summary: SFs significantly reduced bodyweight gain, insulin resistance, neuronal loss, and memory impairment in HFFD-fed mice. They also improved synaptic function, activated beneficial signaling pathways (ERK/CREB/BDNF and IRS-1/AKT), and suppressed inflammatory responses.
population_specificity: High-fat and high-fructose diet-induced obese mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) on the growth of sea buckthorn and soil properties under field conditions at different reclamation times.
results_summary: AMF inoculation significantly improved sea buckthorn survival rates, plant height, crown width, ground diameter, mycorrhizal colonization, soil organic matter, microbial activity, and acid phosphatase activity over a 50-month period.
population_specificity: Sea buckthorn plants in damaged mining areas undergoing ecological restoration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological effects of phenolic compounds from sea buckthorn berries on oxidative stress and hemostasis, comparing them with isorhamnetin and its derivatives.
